newsitem.title: UK: Eurobonds see British TV firm reach wider audience.
newsitem.headline: Eurobonds see British TV firm reach wider audience.

text.p: The primary market remained subdued on Friday morning with many European players still absent from their desks after yesterday's holiday.
The main exception was a 200 million stg 10-year deal from British television company Carlton Communications, its debut in the Euromarket.
Final pricing was due later at a spread of 65 basis points over the key 2006 gilt via lead manager BZW.
Sources close to the issue said while it was an opportunistic financing it was, nevertheless, "a boringly routine transaction".
The Carlton deal was a bit slow, a new issues trader at one of the five co-lead managers said.
"It's definitely not a blow-out deal. The high market means it's not the best moment to launch a sterling deal," he said.
British government bonds have surged this week in the wake of the elction and after major reforms at the Bank of England.
The yield spread between 10-year gilts and German Bunds has narrowed to just over 130 b.p. from around 175 b.p. at the start of the week.

Carlton, which bought the film distribution subsidiary of Rank Group for 65 million stg in early April, is involved with BSkyB and Granada Group in a joint venture called British Digital Broadcasting, which is seeking to win Britain's first licences for digital terrestrial television.
The consortium has pledged to put up to 300 million stg into the venture.
Carlton last December reported pre-tax profits of just under 300 million stg for its financial year ending the previous September.
Also in sterling, Denmark set a 100 million stg three-year deal via Nomura International, which, with its 6.25 percent semi-annual coupon, will be aimed at Japanese investors.
Three-year gilts were yielding around 6.8 percent.
Elsewhere, Deutsche Hypo Hannover raised a 1.0 billion mark Pfandbrief issue due November 2000 via five joint lead managers at a seven basis points spread over German government bonds.
Turkey's long-awaited Eurobond -- a $250 million five-year -- will be launched on Monday, bankers close to the deal said.
Spread talk was 340-350 b.p. over U.S. Treasuries.
Turkey held roadshows in key financial centres in Europe, Asia and the U.S. in April.
International credit rating agencies recently cut Turkey's debt rating. It is rated B by Standard and Poor's and B1 by Moody's.
